channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Paris Attacks Lead French to Reinforce Secular Values in Schools
item.description: The aftermath of the killings at Charlie Hebdo and a kosher market near Paris exposed serious cultural rifts, teachers say.
item.dc:creator: By MAÏA de la BAUME

item.title: Argentine President Now Says Prosecutor’s Death Was Not a Suicide
item.description: President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner said she believed that the lead investigator of the 1994 bombing of a Jewish center did not commit suicide.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN GILBERT and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Obama and Modi See Mutual Benefit in Breaking More Ice
item.description: President Obama is preparing to visit India at a time when American and Indian interests in the region are gradually converging.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Yemeni Government Collapses as President and Prime Minister Resign
item.description: President Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi and his government abruptly stepped down, leaving armed Houthi rebels as the dominant force in a leaderless country.
item.dc:creator: By SHUAIB ALMOSAWA and ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Houthi fighters rode in a truck near the presidential palace on Thursday in Sana.

item.title: White House, Citing Israeli Election, Says Obama and Netanyahu Won’t Meet
item.description: President Obama will not meet with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel when he travels to Washington in March to address a joint session of Congress.
item.dc:creator: By JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Letter From Europe: Anxiety and Division Flourish Amid Europe’s Struggle With Terrorism
item.description: Europe's problems with terror reach deep into national fabrics and will not be resolved by counterterrorism policing alone.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: After the terror attacks in France, the prime minister, Manuel Valls, cited a deep divide in the country.

item.title: Libyan Fighters Seize Benghazi Branch of Central Bank
item.description: The move, by one of the factions battling for control of the country, threatened to set off a scramble for the bank’s vast stores of money and gold.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Libyan fighters seized the Benghazi branch of the country’s central bank on Thursday.

item.title: Ayatollah Khamenei Appeals to Western Youth on Islam and Prejudice
item.description: Iran’s supreme leader released a letter and posted on Twitter after the attacks in Paris by militants who said they acted in the name of Islam.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: World Briefing: Former Iranian Official Gets Jail and $1 Million Fine in Corruption Case
item.description: Mohammad-Reza Rahimi, who was a first vice president under President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, is believed to have been involved in insurance fraud.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Court in Egypt Orders Release of Mubarak’s Sons Pending Corruption Retrial
item.description: The two imprisoned sons of the deposed president Hosni Mubarak came to symbolize self-dealing and corruption under their father’s three-decade rule.
item.dc:creator: By MERNA THOMAS and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Ukraine Cedes Donetsk Airport to Rebels as Fighting Continues
item.description: The airport has not been usable for months, but its loss carried powerful symbolic value for the government in Kiev.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Pro-Russian separatists in Donetsk, Ukraine, on Thursday near a bus that had been shelled. At least eight people were killed.

item.title: Libyan Fighters Sieze Benghazi Branch of Central Bank
item.description: The attack, by one of the factions battling for control of the country, threatened to set off an scramble for the bank’s vast stores of money and gold.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: E.C.B. Stimulus Calls for 60 Billion Euros in Monthly Bond-Buying
item.description: The program, worth about $69.7 billion a month, is more than analysts had been expecting as the European Central Bank tries to fend off stagnation.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY and JACK EWING
item.media:description: Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, speaking on Thursday about the long-awaited quantitative easing program.

item.title: Ex-Lawmaker’s Sentence for Encouraging Revolt Is Upheld in South Korea
item.description: Lee Seok-ki, whose small, leftist United Progressive Party was disbanded by a court last month, was arrested in 2013 on charges including treason.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: In Myanmar’s ‘Black Zones,’ Illicit Chinese Commerce Is Said to Thrive
item.description: Recent reports about the possibility of Chinese citizens being trapped in Kachin State are a reminder of China’s dealings in Myanmar.
item.dc:creator: By JONAH M. KESSEL
item.media:credit: Jonah M. Kessel/The New York Times
item.media:description: An image from a video shows Chinese citizens purchasing jade in Hpakant, Myanmar. The area is supposed to be off limits to all foreigners.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: What Does Pegida Say About Germany?
item.description: Despite anti-immigrant protests, the nation is more tolerant than ever.
item.dc:creator: By ANNA SAUERBREY

item.title: Divers Begin Hauling Up Bodies From Sunken AirAsia Plane
item.description: Until Thursday, severe currents and surface waves as high as 16 feet had prevented divers from reaching the fuselage or trying to raise it to the surface.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE

item.title: Japan Says Efforts to Contact Islamic State About Hostages Have Failed
item.description: Officials said they were trying every avenue to reach the militants who have threatened to kill two Japanese men, as time runs out on a ransom deadline.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: At Least 7 Killed in Shelling of City Bus in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: The shell struck the vehicle Thursday in Donetsk, instantly killing numerous passengers and blowing out the windows of a nearby building.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Pro-Russian separatists on a street in Donetsk on Thursday after least seven people were killed when a city bus was hit by an artillery shell.

item.title: View From Abroad: Africa’s Economy Is Rising. Now What Happens to Its Food?
item.description: A continent that has long struggled economically is at last poised to make real progress, but it now faces crucial questions, many involving food.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID LEONHARDT
item.media:description: Rice farming in eastern Rwanda last year. Africa’s farmers are vastly less productive than farmers elsewhere, which needs to change in order for the continent to catch up economically.
